awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Nonlinear stability mechanisms and boundary layer singularities in fluid flows
awd_abstract_narration:
The project concerns the mathematical analysis of fluid flows in the vicinity of physical boundaries, a fundamental problem in fluid dynamics. The realization that drag forces exerted on a body moving through air (or water) take place on a thin layer around the body lead to the development of boundary layer theory. The practical importance of boundary layer theory in aerodynamics and hydrodynamics is immense: computing the drag on an object and the energy dissipation rate nearby, with implications for fuel efficiency; understanding the problem of wing stall, the dependence of the lift on the angle of attack; and even the enhancement of heat transfer near solid walls. Mathematically, these questions concern the behavior of solutions to the Navier-Stokes equations in the vanishing viscosity limit, and the stability of the ensuing boundary layers.  This project will develop new analytical tools to study the validity of the vanishing viscosity limit, the formation of singularities in boundary layers, and to explore the nonlinear stability mechanisms by which these lead to dynamic boundary layer separation. This theoretical information will lead to more accurate reduced models and finer predictions about real fluid flows. The project will train undergraduate, graduate, and post-graduate researchers, in modern research problems in applied mathematics and the tools to study them.

This project aims to develop new mathematical tools that will further our understanding of the vanishing viscosity limit: the question whether solutions of the incompressible Navier-Stokes equations converge to solutions of the incompressible Euler equations as the viscosity approaches zero, in the presence of a characteristic physical boundary. For fixed external parameters, the vanishing viscosity limit is equivalent to the infinite Reynolds number limit, and thus this problem is of vital importance to the study of the onset of turbulence in fluid flows. The PI and collaborators will address the emergence of singularities in the Prandtl boundary layer equations by establishing more robust finite time blow-up scenarios. The stability of nearly laminar boundary layers will be studied via a hypocoercive analysis of the Prandtl system and of higher order models. Finally, the PI will develop new energy methods that intertwine Eulerian and Lagrangian approaches to prove the vanishing viscosity limit in high regularity regimes. The goal is to develop nonlinear, solution-adapted methods. Graduate students and post-doctoral fellows will be mentored and included in the research activities.

por.por_cntn:
This project was focused on developing new mathematical techniques for extending our understanding of fluid flow in the infinite Reynolds number limit, one of the fundamental problems in mathematical fluid dynamics.

The central issue is to determine whether solutions of the incompressible Navier-Stokes equations display anomalous dissipation of kinetic energy in the vanishing viscosity limit (infinite Reynolds number limit). This anomalous dissipation has been observed experimentally to a large degree but insofar lacks a fully rigorous mathematical understanding. The rate of dissipation of kinetic energy is proportional to the drag force exerted on a body moving through the fluid (or air), and practically it is well-understood that thin layers around the body (boundary layers) are primarily responsible for the bulk of these drag forces. Understanding the behavior of drag coefficients as a function of an (increasingly large) Reynolds number is a classical subject in the applied mathematics and engineering literature, due to its immense practical importance: implications for fuel efficiency, the problem of wing stall, and even the heat transfer near solid walls. From a mathematical perspective, the aforementioned problem is intimately related to the question of the vanishing viscosity limit: whether solutions of the incompressible Navier-Stokes equations converge to solutions of the incompressible Euler equations, as the viscosity approaches zero.

Intellectual Merit.

First, the project considered the infinite Reynolds number limit in the presence of a characteristic physical boundary. In this case, the solutions were taken to be smooth, but obeying bounds that degenerate as the Reynolds number diverges, due to the emergence of strong boundary layers. The PI and collaborators have established the vanishing viscosity limit and the validity of the Prandtl expansion for initial data which is analytic in the vicinity of the solid wall but has only limited regularity away from this boundary. This result implies all other known results concerning the strong vanishing viscosity limit. The PI and collaborators have also obtained the first mathematically rigorous existence and uniqueness result for the Triple Deck higher-order boundary layer model.


Second, the project considered the behavior of fluids at infinite Reynolds number (i.e., for the Euler equations), in the absence of physical boundaries, but in the context of singular weak solutions. Weak solutions are capable by themselves to anomalously dissipate energy, without friction, due to bulk singularities. The PI and collaborators have given a new, independent, proof of the flexible side of the Onsager conjecture. They constructed non-conservative weak solutions to the 3D incompressible Euler equations whose regularity lies at the Onsager regularity threshold, and which display intermittent features akin to those observed in fully developed turbulent flows. The PI and collaborators have also employed a rigorous renormalization argument from the theory of quantitative homogenization to simultaneously analyze a forward energy cascade and a backward cascade of eddy diffusivities in passive scalar turbulence.

Broader Impacts.

The mathematical advances put forth by this project have been disseminated in research articles that are now published in leading academic journals. The PI has co-authored a textbook on mathematical fluid dynamics (incompressible), which will hopefully influence a new generation of researchers. During the award period, the grant also supported the education and research of several Ph.D. students; one has since completed their degree and is continuing their career in academia. The PI has also mentored several postdoctoral researchers; two of whom now hold tenure-track academic jobs at top-tier research institutions.
